newsitem.title: INDIA: FOCUS-Japanese FIRMS detail India investment plans.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Japanese FIRMS detail India investment plans.

text.p: Japan's Mitsubishi Corp is discussing a clutch of high-profile investments in India topped by a $2.0 billion telecommunications joint venture, a senior Mitsubishi official said on Monday.
Mitsubishi was one of several Japanese investors that unveiled plans for India on Monday. A record 132 Japanese firms are represented at an engineering trade fair in New Delhi.
The surge in interest was in contrast with warnings at a seminar elsewhere in the Indian capital on Monday that the country must quickly tear down barriers to trade and investment.
K. Yoshizawa, deputy president of the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd, told the seminar that India attracted a meagre $2.5 billion of foreign direct investment in 1996 compared with China's $40 billion.

"The big gap does suggest no time should be lost in removing the factors that stand in the way of capital inflows," he said. "The amount of red tape is so appalling that it is critically eroding India's competitiveness in attracting foreign capital."
Parvesh Gulati, manager of Mitsubishi Corp's New Delhi liaison office, told Reuters the proposed telecom project would involve basic telephone services.
The Japanese company was in talks with the Tata group, India's largest private-sector group, and RPG Telecom Ltd, he said.
"If we get a good proposal in telecom, we are definitely thinking of a new joint venture," Gulati said.
Separately, Marubeni Corp said it had earmarked $100 million for investment in India over the next three years in textiles, automobiles, metals and petrochemicals.

Liquefied petroleum gas distributor Iwatani International Corp said it was in talks with state-controlled Indian Oil Corp Ltd (IOC) to build an LPG import terminal in India, a project that could involve investment of up to $10 million.

"We'd like to cooperate with an Indian company in this, and we are already in contact with IOC," a company official said. He said the two firms were planning to establish a joint venture with equal equity stakes.
And financial information services group Nihon Keizai Shimbun Inc (Nikkei) said it wanted to sell on-line information in English in India.
"We are looking for an agent in India to sell our service, but we are ready to provide it from today," Hideto Onishi of Nikkei's information system department told Reuters.
Japan is India's biggest donor, offering 133.7 billion yen ($1.1 billion) in overseas development assistance (ODA), or aid, in the 1996/97 fiscal year which will end on March 31.
But it is only the fourth largest investor in India, ranked behind the United States, Germany and Britain.
Mitsubishi said it was also in talks with India's Essar Steel Ltd and Tata Iron and Steel Co Ltd to set up a joint venture company that would make construction, steel and port equipment.
"That will involve $10 million minimum, but it could mean up to $50 million -- that depends on the project," Mitsubishi's Gulati said.
The firm was also discussing building India's first methyl methacrylate (MMA) plant with Indian Petrochemicals Corp Ltd and the Aditya Birla group, he said.
A decision on the project, which would entail investment of $150 million to $250 million, was due by year-end, he said.
Mitsubishi was scheduled later this week to a sign a $10 million joint venture agreement with India's JBM Group to produce metal parts for Hyundai Motor Co Ltd.

Mitsubishi Chemical Corp, a subsidiary of Mitsubishi Corp, was in the process of negotiating a $350 million contract for a turn-key petrochemicals plant in Haldia town, in the eastern state of West Bengal, Gulati said.
